Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Oleg Lunin at the University at Albany (SUNY).

Two of the most important open problems in theoretical physics are a construction of a consistent theory of quantum gravity and an analytical understanding of the strong interaction. These subjects are unified in the framework of gauge/gravity duality, which translates difficult problems in the theory of strong interactions into simple questions in gravity and vice versa. This research project will utilize the techniques of gauge/gravity duality to get insights into quantum properties of black holes and into dynamics of strongly-coupled gauge theories. The first part of the project will focus of resolving the black hole information paradox by identifying the microscopic states contributing to the entropy of various black holes and by studying their dynamics. The second part of the project will focus on understanding dynamics of strongly--coupled gauge theories by studying the dual description in terms of classical geometries.

This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Specifically, Professor Lunin will give lectures to high school students in the Albany area to inspire the students to consider careers in STEM and to prepare them for entering these quantitative fields. In addition, Professor Lunin will organize annual physics competitions, which will help the students to sharpen their problem-solving skills. He will also mentor graduate students and provide career advice to undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two of the most important open problems in theoretical physics are a construction of a consistent theory of quantum gravity and an analytic understanding of the strong interaction. The eight publications supported by this award led to advances in both areas by studying quantum properties of black holes and by constructing several solvable examples of strongly-coupled systems.

The last two decades witnessed great improvements in our understanding of quantum gravity and strongly-coupled systems.  A special role in this progress has been played by integrability, a remarkable property that allows one to solve field and string theories. Originally integrable structures were discovered in several isolated examples, but in the last few years they have been extended to continuous families of string theories, and this progress gives a hope of finding solvable models providing good approximations to realistic systems. The research supported by this award contributed to study of integrability by constructing three large families of solvable string theories and by ruling out integrability of strings on a large class of promising backgrounds.

Specifically, three papers supported by this award contributed to development of procedures which can be used to generate continuous families of integrable string theories starting from an isolated solvable system. These three constructions encompass the largest known families of integrable string theories. A separate but related work supported by this award resulted in classification of supersymmetric geometries with integrable geodesics, and this analysis had several applications to integrability of strings and to study of black holes.

The extension of this work to backgrounds without supersymmetry led to a comprehensive study of hidden symmetries in string theory and supergravity. Such structures are encoded in so-called Killing-Yano tensors, and one of the investigations supported by this award resulted in discovering the unique modification of the Killing-Yano equation consistent with string dualities. This work also resulted in explicit construction of the Killing-Yano tensors for charged rotating black holes in arbitrary dimensions.
Hidden symmetries of black rings were also analyzed in a separate paper. The results of these investigations will facilitate future studies of particles and fields in the vicinity of black holes, which can shed new light on the Hawking radiation, the information paradox, and on other quantum properties of black holes.

The issues associated with the black hole information paradox were addressed more directly in two additional papers supported by this award. The paradox arises from combining general relativity with quantum mechanics: the former predicts the existence of black holes, the latter gives a mechanism for their evaporation, and the information appears to be lost in this process. A promising approach to resolution of the information paradox, which became known as the `fuzzball proposal', replaces the traditional view of a black hole as empty space separating  singularity and horizon by superposition of regular geometries. Construction of such microscopic states is one of the main challenges of the `fuzzball program', and in the past this task has been completed for some microscopic states of five-dimensional black holes. One of the papers supported by this award initiated the application of the fuzzball proposal to four--dimensional black holes by constructing the first set of regular geometries contributing to entropy of such holes. This work also uncovered a new mechanism for regularization, which is based on some peculiar topological features of new states.  A separate work was focused on finding new classes of regular geometries describing macroscopic five-dimensional black holes.

The broader impact of this project focused on stimulating interest in science among high school and college students and on disseminating scientific knowledge among the general public. Specifically, the PI created a mini--course on particle physics for students from local high schools, organized annual physics competitions, served as a judge for annual science fairs, and presented several lectures to the general public.
